headline: Triple Ginger Gingerbread Cake
description: Time for gingerbread! This old-fashioned gingerbread cake is loaded with three kinds of ginger: ground, fresh, and candied. It's an extra-special treat to have around the holidays.
name: Triple Ginger Gingerbread Cake
keywords: Baking, Cake, Christmas, Ginger, Gingerbread, Holiday, Molasses, American, Dessert, Favorite Winter
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup honey (preferably a dark variety such as buckwheat, avocado or wildflower)
1/2 cup dark brown sugar (can substitute light brown)
1 tablespoon fresh ginger, peeled and finely grated

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven and prep baking dish: Preheat oven to 325°F. Butter and lightly flour an 8 x 8-inch or 9 x 9-inch baking dish. Fit a piece of parchment or baking paper inside and allow some to hang off the sides (this will make it easier to lift the cake out of the pan later). Lightly butter and flour the paper as well.

Melt the butter with molasses, honey, water, brown sugar: In a medium saucepan over medium heat place the butter, molasses, honey, water, and brown sugar. Stir to melt the butter. Do not allow to simmer or boil. Once the butter is melted, take the pot off the heat and allow to cool to room temperature. Be sure to stir the mixture every so often as the sugar and fat will form a skin on the surface.
Add the eggs and ginger: Once the butter mixture is at room temperature whisk the eggs, grated ginger, and candied ginger into the molasses mixture. Set aside.
Whisk the flour, baking soda, and spices: Whisk together the flour, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, cloves, and nutmeg.
Add the flour to the molasses mixture: Add the flour mixture in 3 or 4 additions and whisk until it just comes together.
Bake: Pour into the prepared pan and bake for 35 minutes. Loosely place a piece of foil over the top and bake for another 15 to 25 minutes or until a tester comes out clean.

Cool: Cool on a wire rack for ten minutes, then lift the cake out of the pan and continue to cool on the rack. You can serve this fresh out of the oven, but the flavor is much better if you give it a day to sit and allow the spices to intensify.

review.reviewBody: This was delicious, but the next time I make it I will leave the candied ginger in larger pieces — I minced it too finely and it disappeared into the cake, whereas I think it would be even better in slightly larger pieces that retain the character of candied ginger after baking.

It came out delicious. My work peeps all loved it. Changes I made: bundt cake pan and I omitted the candied and fresh ginger since I had none (I put in another half tsp of my powdered ginger). All your recipes are so good that they can handle a couple of small tweaks and come out just fine.

I think the trick to this recipe is measuring the liquid ingredients as if they were dry- using the same measuring cups for the whole recipe. Truly old-fashioned. Then, it's this heavenly heavenly thing. I made a few other tweaks I used buckwheat honey as suggested. So good! Definitely do that! And I added 2 tablespoons of apple sauce, subbed in a 1/4 cup of oat flour for regular flour, and doubled the candied ginger. Based on the comments below, I adjusted the cooking time, and baked the cake at 350 for 45 minutes, then covered with foil and baked 10 minutes more. That did the trick.
 Served with caramel sauce, it's a bit like sticky toffee pudding. Hard not to eat all at once.

Made this today, pretty much exactly as described. Maybe upped the ginger of all kinds a bit. I'm glad you showed a picture with the center a little sunken, because that's how mine turned out. Wonderful and thank you.
Could you subsitute some or all the flour for oat flour?
